org.apache.juneau.rest

Class RestContext

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.apache.juneau.Context
      • org.apache.juneau.rest.RestContext

  • public final class RestContext
extends Context
    Contains all the configuration on a REST resource and the entry points for handling REST calls.

    See PropertyStore for more information about context properties.

    • Field Detail

      • REST_allowHeaderParams

        public static final String REST_allowHeaderParams
        Configuration property: Enable header URL parameters.

        • Name: "RestServlet.allowHeaderParams"
        • Data type: Boolean
        • Default: true

        When enabled, headers such as "Accept" and "Content-Type" to be passed in as URL query parameters. For example: "?Accept=text/json&Content-Type=text/json"

        Parameter names are case-insensitive.

        Useful for debugging REST interface using only a browser.

        Applicable to servlet class only.

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • REST_allowMethodParam

        public static final String REST_allowMethodParam
        Configuration property: Enable "method" URL parameter for specific HTTP methods.

        • Name: "RestServlet.allowMethodParam"
        • Data type: String
        • Default: ""

        When specified, the HTTP method can be overridden by passing in a "method" URL parameter on a regular GET request. For example: "?method=OPTIONS"

        Format is a comma-delimited list of HTTP method names that can be passed in as a method parameter. Parameter name is case-insensitive. Use "*" to represent all methods. For backwards compatibility, "true" also means "*".

        Note that per the HTTP specification, special care should be taken when allowing non-safe (POST, PUT, DELETE) methods to be invoked through GET requests.

        Applicable to servlet class only.

        Example: "HEAD,OPTIONS"

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • REST_allowBodyParam

        public static final String REST_allowBodyParam
        Configuration property: Enable "body" URL parameter.

        • Name: "RestServlet.allowBodyParam"
        • Data type: Boolean
        • Default: true

        When enabled, the HTTP body content on PUT and POST requests can be passed in as text using the "body" URL parameter. For example: "?body={name:'John%20Smith',age:45}"

        Parameter name is case-insensitive.

        Useful for debugging PUT and POST methods using only a browser.

        Applicable to servlet class only.

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • REST_renderResponseStackTraces

        public static final String REST_renderResponseStackTraces
        Configuration property: Render stack traces.

        • Name: "RestServlet.renderResponseStackTraces"
        • Data type: Boolean
        • Default: false

        Render stack traces in HTTP response bodies when errors occur.

        When enabled, Java stack traces will be rendered in the output response. Useful for debugging, although allowing stack traces to be rendered may cause security concerns.

        Applicable to servlet class only.

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • REST_useStackTraceHashes

        public static final String REST_useStackTraceHashes
        Configuration property: Use stack trace hashes.

        • Name: "RestServlet.useStackTraceHashes"
        • Data type: Boolean
        • Default: true

        When enabled, the number of times an exception has occurred will be determined based on stack trace hashsums, made available through the RestException.getOccurrence() method.

        Applicable to servlet class only.

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • REST_defaultCharset

        public static final String REST_defaultCharset
        Configuration property: Default character encoding.

        • Name: "RestServlet.defaultCharset"
        • Data type: String
        • Default: "utf-8"

        The default character encoding for the request and response if not specified on the request.

        Applicable to servlet class and methods.

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • REST_paramFormat

        public static final String REST_paramFormat
        Configuration property: Expected format of request parameters.

        • Name: "RestServlet.paramFormat"
        • Data type: String
        • Default: "UON"

        Possible values:

        • "UON" - URL-Encoded Object Notation.
          This notation allows for request parameters to contain arbitrarily complex POJOs.
        • "PLAIN" - Plain text.
          This treats request parameters as plain text.
          Only POJOs directly convertable from Strings can be represented in parameters when using this mode.

        Note that the parameter value "(foo)" is interpreted as "(foo)" when using plain mode, but "foo" when using UON mode.

        The format can also be specified per-parameter using the @FormData.format() and @Query.format() annotations.

        Applicable to servlet class and methods.

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • REST_servletPath

        public static final String REST_servletPath
        The request servlet path.

        Automatically added to properties returned by Session.getProperty(String) and Session.getProperty(String).

        Equivalent to the value returned by HttpServletRequestWrapper.getServletPath()

    • Method Detail

      • getVarResolver

        public VarResolver getVarResolver()
        Returns the variable resolver for this servlet.

        Variable resolvers are used to replace variables in property values.

        Example:

        @RestResource( messages="nls/Messages", properties={ @Property(name="title",value="$L{title}"), // Localized variable in Messages.properties @Property(name="javaVendor",value="$S{java.vendor,Oracle}"), // System property with default value @Property(name="foo",value="bar"), @Property(name="bar",value="baz"), @Property(name="v1",value="$R{foo}"), // Request variable. value="bar" @Property(name="v2",value="$R{$R{foo}}") // Nested request variable. value="baz" } ) public class MyRestResource extends RestServletDefault {

        A typical usage pattern is using variables for resolving URL links when rendering HTML:

        @RestMethod( name="GET", path="/{name}/*", properties={ @Property( name=HTMLDOC_links, value="{up:'$R{requestParentURI}', options:'?method=OPTIONS', editLevel:'editLevel?logger=$R{attribute.name}'}" ) } ) public LoggerEntry getLogger(RestRequest req, @Path String name) throws Exception {

        Calls to req.getProperties().getString("key") returns strings with variables resolved.

        Returns:
        The var resolver in use by this resource.

      • getConfigFile

        public ConfigFile getConfigFile()
        Returns the config file associated with this servlet.

        The config file is identified via one of the following:

        • @RestResource.config() annotation.
        • RestConfig.setConfigFile(ConfigFile) method.
        Returns:
        The resolving config file associated with this servlet. Never null.

      • resolveStaticFile

        public StreamResource resolveStaticFile(String pathInfo)
                                 throws IOException
        Resolve a static resource file.

        The location of static resources are defined via one of the following:

        • @RestResource.staticFiles() annotation.
        • RestConfig.addStaticFiles(Class, String) method.
        Parameters:
        pathInfo - The unencoded path info.
        Returns:
        The resource, or null if the resource could not be resolved.
        Throws:
        IOException

      • getResource

        protected InputStream getResource(String name,
                                  Locale locale)
                           throws IOException
        Same as Class.getResourceAsStream(String) except if it doesn't find the resource on this class, searches up the parent hierarchy chain.

        If the resource cannot be found in the classpath, then an attempt is made to look in the JVM working directory.

        If the locale is specified, then we look for resources whose name matches that locale. For example, if looking for the resource "MyResource.txt" for the Japanese locale, we will look for files in the following order:

        1. "MyResource_ja_JP.txt"
        2. "MyResource_ja.txt"
        3. "MyResource.txt"
        Parameters:
        name - The resource name.
        locale - Optional locale.
        Returns:
        An input stream of the resource, or null if the resource could not be found.
        Throws:
        IOException

      • getResourceAsString

        public String getResourceAsString(String name,
                                  Locale locale)
                           throws IOException
        Reads the input stream from getResource(String, Locale) into a String.
        Parameters:
        name - The resource name.
        locale - Optional locale.
        Returns:
        The contents of the stream as a string, or null if the resource could not be found.
        Throws:
        IOException - If resource could not be found.

      • getResource

        public <T> T getResource(Class<T> c,
                         MediaType mediaType,
                         String name,
                         Locale locale)
                  throws IOException,
                         ServletException
        Reads the input stream from getResource(String, Locale) and parses it into a POJO using the parser matched by the specified media type.

        Useful if you want to load predefined POJOs from JSON files in your classpath.

        Parameters:
        c - The class type of the POJO to create.
        mediaType - The media type of the data in the stream (e.g. "text/json")
        name - The resource name (e.g. "htdocs/styles.css").
        locale - Optional locale.
        Returns:
        The parsed resource, or null if the resource could not be found.
        Throws:
        IOException
        ServletException - If the media type was unknown or the input could not be parsed into a POJO.

      • getPath

        public String getPath()
        Returns the path for this resource as defined by the RestResource.path() annotation or RestConfig.setPath(String) method concatenated with those on all parent classes.

        If path is not specified, returns "/".

        Path always starts with "/".

        Returns:
        The servlet path.

      • getParentContext

        public RestContext getParentContext()
        Returns the parent resource context (if this resource was initialized from a parent).

        From this object, you can get access to the parent resource class itself using getResource() or getRestServlet()

        Returns:
        The parent resource context, or null if there is no parent context.

      • getProperties

        public ObjectMap getProperties()
        Returns the class-level properties associated with this servlet.

        Properties at the class level are defined via one of the following:

        • @RestResource.properties() annotation.
        • RestConfig.setProperty(String, Object)/RestConfig.setProperties(Map) methods.

        Notes:
        • The returned Map is mutable. Therefore, subclasses are free to override or set additional initialization parameters in their init() method.
        Returns:
        The resource properties as an ObjectMap.

      • getClientVersionHeader

        protected String getClientVersionHeader()
        Returns the name of the client version header name used by this resource.

        The client version header is the name of the HTTP header on requests that identify a client version.

        The client version header is defined via one of the following:

        • @RestResource.clientVersion() annotation.
        Returns:
        The name of the client version header used by this resource. Never null.

        Returns:
        true if this resource allows the specified method to be overridden.

      • findParams

        protected RestParam[] findParams(Method method,
                                 boolean methodPlainParams,
                                 UrlPathPattern pathPattern)
                          throws ServletException
        Finds the RestParam instances to handle resolving objects on the calls to the specified Java method.
        Parameters:
        method - The Java method being called.
        methodPlainParams - Whether plain-params setting is specified.
        pathPattern - The parsed URL path pattern.
        Returns:
        The array of resolvers.
        Throws:
        ServletException - If an annotation usage error was detected.

        protected EncoderGroup getEncoders()
        Returns the encoders associated with this resource.

        Encoders are used to provide various types of encoding such as gzip encoding.

        Encoders at the class level are defined via one of the following:

        • @RestResource.encoders() annotation.
        • RestConfig.addEncoders(Class...)/RestConfig.addEncoders(org.apache.juneau.encoders.Encoder...) methods.
        Returns:
        The encoders associated with this resource. Never null.

      • getSupportedAcceptTypes

        protected MediaType[] getSupportedAcceptTypes()
        Returns the explicit list of supported accept types for this resource.

        By default, this is simply the list of accept types supported by the registered parsers, but can be overridden via the RestConfig.setSupportedAcceptTypes(MediaType...)/RestConfig.setSupportedAcceptTypes(String...) methods.

        Returns:
        The supported Accept header values for this resource. Never null.

      • getSupportedContentTypes

        protected MediaType[] getSupportedContentTypes()
        Returns the explicit list of supported content types for this resource.

        By default, this is simply the list of content types supported by the registered serializers, but can be overridden via the RestConfig.setSupportedContentTypes(MediaType...)/RestConfig.setSupportedContentTypes(String...) methods.

        Returns:
        The supported Content-Type header values for this resource. Never null.

      • getDefaultRequestHeaders

        protected Map<String,String> getDefaultRequestHeaders()
        Returns the default request headers for this resource.

        These are headers automatically added to requests if not present.

        Default request headers are defined via one of the following:

        • @RestResource.defaultRequestHeaders() annotation.
        • RestConfig.addDefaultRequestHeader(String, Object)/RestConfig.addDefaultRequestHeaders(String...) methods.
        Returns:
        The default request headers for this resource. Never null.

      • getDefaultResponseHeaders

        public Map<String,Object> getDefaultResponseHeaders()
        Returns the default response headers for this resource.

        These are headers automatically added to responses if not otherwise specified during the request.

        Default response headers are defined via one of the following:

        • @RestResource.defaultResponseHeaders() annotation.
        • RestConfig.addDefaultResponseHeader(String, Object)/RestConfig.addDefaultResponseHeaders(String...) methods.
        Returns:
        The default response headers for this resource. Never null.

      • getConverters

        protected RestConverter[] getConverters()
        Returns the converters associated with this resource at the class level.

        Converters are used to 'convert' POJOs from one form to another before being passed of to the response handlers.

        Converters at the class level are defined via one of the following:

        • @RestResource.converters() annotation.
        • RestConfig.addConverters(Class...)/RestConfig.addConverters(RestConverter...) methods.
        Returns:
        The converters associated with this resource. Never null.

      • getGuards

        protected RestGuard[] getGuards()
        Returns the guards associated with this resource at the class level.

        Guards are used to restrict access to resources.

        Guards at the class level are defined via one of the following:

        • @RestResource.guards() annotation.
        • RestConfig.addGuards(Class...)/RestConfig.addGuards(RestGuard...) methods.
        Returns:
        The guards associated with this resource. Never null.

      • getResponseHandlers

        protected ResponseHandler[] getResponseHandlers()
        Returns the response handlers associated with this resource.

        Response handlers are used to convert POJOs returned by REST Java methods into actual HTTP responses.

        Response handlers are defined via one of the following:

        • @RestResource.responseHandlers() annotation.
        • RestConfig.addResponseHandlers(Class...)/RestConfig.addResponseHandlers(ResponseHandler...) methods.
        Returns:
        The response handlers associated with this resource. Never null.

      • getMediaTypeForName

        protected String getMediaTypeForName(String name)
        Returns the media type for the specified file name.

        The list of MIME-type mappings can be augmented through the RestConfig.addMimeTypes(String...) method. See that method for a description of predefined MIME-type mappings.

        Parameters:
        name - The file name.
        Returns:
        The MIME-type, or null if it could not be determined.

      • getFavIcon

        protected StreamResource getFavIcon()
        Returns the favicon of the resource.

        This is the icon served up under "/favicon.ico" recognized by browsers.

        The favicon is defined via one of the following:

        • @RestResource.favicon() annotation.
        • RestConfig.setFavIcon(Object)/RestConfig.setFavIcon(Class, String) methods.
        Returns:
        The favicon of this resource. Can be null.

      • getStyleSheet

        protected StreamResource getStyleSheet()
        Returns the stylesheet for use in the HTML views of the resource.

        This is the contents of the page served up under "/styles.css".

        The stylesheet is defined via one of the following:

        • @RestResource.stylesheet() annotation.
        • RestConfig.setStyleSheet(Object...)/RestConfig.setStyleSheet(Class, String) methods.
        Returns:
        The aggregated stylesheet of this resource. Never null.

      • isStaticFile

        protected boolean isStaticFile(String p)
        Returns true if the specified path refers to a static file.

        Static files are files pulled from the classpath and served up directly to the browser.

        Static files are defined via one of the following:

        • @RestResource.staticFiles() annotation.
        • RestConfig.addStaticFiles(Class, String) method.
        Parameters:
        p - The URL path remainder after the servlet match.
        Returns:
        true if the specified path refers to a static file.

      • getCallMethods

        protected Map<String,org.apache.juneau.rest.CallMethod> getCallMethods()
        Returns the REST Java methods defined in this resource.

        These are the methods annotated with the @RestMethod annotation.

        Returns:
        A map of Java method names to call method objects.

      • destroy

        protected void destroy()
        Calls Servlet.destroy() on any child resources defined on this resource.

      • hasChildResources

        protected boolean hasChildResources()
        Returns true if this resource has any child resources associated with it.
        Returns:
        true if this resource has any child resources associated with it.

      • getChildResource

        protected RestContext getChildResource(String path)
        Returns the context of the child resource associated with the specified path.
        Parameters:
        path - The path of the child resource to resolve.
        Returns:
        The resolved context, or null if it could not be resolved.
